1: a)  Data hiding and protection from outside access.
b)  Defining the relationship between classes.
d)  Creating multiple instances of a class.
3: a)  The ability of a class to inherit from multiple parent classes.
b)  The process of creating new objects from a class.
c)  The ability of an object to take on many forms.
d)  The process of hiding data within a class.
4: a)  Create multiple instances of the same class.
b)  Acquire properties and methods from parent classes.
c)  Restrict access to certain class members.
d)  Overload operators within a class.
5: a)  To destroy an object when it's no longer needed.
b)  To define the methods of the class.
c)  To initialize the object's attributes when the object is created.
d)  To inherit properties from a parent class.
6: a)  Overloading defines multiple methods with the same name and different parameters within the same class; overriding defines a method in a child class that has the same name and parameters as a method in a parent class.
b)  Overloading defines multiple methods with the same name and parameters; overriding renames a method in the child class.
c)  Overloading is used for constructors only; overriding is used for other methods.
d)  There is no difference; they are interchangeable terms.
7: a) A class that cannot be instantiated directly.
b) A class that contains only static methods.
c) A class that has no methods.
d) A class that is automatically created by the compiler.
9: a)  A class that cannot be instantiated.
b)  A blueprint that defines methods a class must implement.
c)  A method that handles exceptions.
d)  A way to create multiple instances of a class.
10: b) To prevent program crashes due to runtime errors.
c) To increase program execution speed.
